description: Coined, theo- +‎ -ism. ultimately from Ancient Greek θεός (theós, “god”). Attested in English from 1678, theist being attested 16 years earlier in 1662. Cognate French théisme,, as in Diderot Principes de la philosophie morale (1745), which was probably borrowed from English.

entries.meaning: Belief in the existence of at least one deity.

(strictly) Belief in the existence of a personal creator god, goddess, gods and/or goddesses present and active in the governance and organization of the world and the universe. The God may be known by or through revelation.
examples: The term stands in contradistinction to theism which, in its widest sense, means belief in a personal god, goddess, gods and/or goddesses.

description: Borrowing from New Latin thea (“tea”, noun) + English -ism.

entries.meaning: A morbid condition resulting from excessive consumption of tea.
